articles.headline: What if a Healthier Facebook Is Just … Instagram?
articles.snippet: As Facebook undergoes a renovation focused on improving its users’ well-being, the company could take inspiration from an app it already owns.
articles.abstract: As Facebook undergoes a renovation focused on improving its users’ well-being, the company could take inspiration from an app it already owns.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past several years, Facebook has been conducting what amounts to an A/B test on human society, using two different social media apps.

articles.headline: China’s Housing Market Is Like a Casino. Can a Property Tax Tame It?
articles.snippet: Officials appear to be warming to the idea of imposing the country’s first national tax on homes to cool a market subject to wild booms and busts.
articles.abstract: Officials appear to be warming to the idea of imposing the country’s first national tax on homes to cool a market subject to wild booms and busts.
articles.lead_paragraph: NANJING, China — China has tried just about everything to tame a property market in which home prices sometimes jump around like the value of Bitcoin.

articles.headline: Bonuses Aside, Tax Law’s Trickle-Down Impact Not Yet Clear
articles.snippet: Companies are announcing bonuses as a result of the tax cuts but it remains to be seen how much of that money will filter through to workers in the years to come.
articles.abstract: Companies are announcing bonuses as a result of the tax cuts but it remains to be seen how much of that money will filter through to workers in the years to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are good ways to start measuring how much the Trump tax cuts might be helping American workers. Tracking the bonus announcements flowing from corporations is not one of them.

articles.headline: Trump Slaps Steep Tariffs on Foreign Washing Machines and Solar Products
articles.snippet: The Trump administration said it would impose steep tariffs on imports, the first major step by the administration to erect the kind of barriers the president frequently threatened.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration said it would impose steep tariffs on imports, the first major step by the administration to erect the kind of barriers the president frequently threatened.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump slapped steep tariffs on imports of washing machines and solar energy cells and panels on Monday, the first major step by the administration to erect the kind of trade barriers Mr. Trump has frequently said are necessary to protect manufacturers in the United States.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Brad Plumer

articles.headline: Government Shutdown Ends After 3 Days of Recriminations
articles.snippet: With a promise that lawmakers would soon take up immigration, Congress approved a short-term spending bill to reopen the government after a brief but heated shutdown.
articles.abstract: With a promise that lawmakers would soon take up immigration, Congress approved a short-term spending bill to reopen the government after a brief but heated shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress brought an end to a three-day government shutdown on Monday as Senate Democrats buckled under pressure to adopt a short-term spending bill to fund government operations without first addressing the fate of young undocumented immigrants.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: As Turkey Attacks Kurds in Syria, U.S. Is on the Sideline
articles.snippet: Turkish forces continued their attack on the Kurds, America’s closest ally in the war on the Islamic State, with the apparent blessing of Moscow.
articles.abstract: Turkish forces continued their attack on the Kurds, America’s closest ally in the war on the Islamic State, with the apparent blessing of Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump met with Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, at the United Nations last September, he embraced him as a friend and declared, “We’re as close as we’ve ever been.” Five months later, Turkey is waging an all-out assault against Syrian Kurds, America’s closest allies in the war against the Islamic State.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: Democrats Blink in Shutdown Impasse, Hoping for a Bargain
articles.snippet: Senate Democrats believe they are limiting damage from a political miscalculation by surrendering, but doing so has drawn a fierce backlash from the left.
articles.abstract: Senate Democrats believe they are limiting damage from a political miscalculation by surrendering, but doing so has drawn a fierce backlash from the left.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats blinked. But the saving grace for them may be that they did it quickly.

articles.headline: Murdoch’s Bid for Full Control of Sky Is Dealt a Blow by U.K. Regulator
articles.snippet: The Competition and Markets Authority provisionally rejected 21st Century Fox’s proposed deal for the part of the satellite broadcaster it doesn’t already control.
articles.abstract: The Competition and Markets Authority provisionally rejected 21st Century Fox’s proposed deal for the part of the satellite broadcaster it doesn’t already control.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rupert Murdoch’s yearslong effort to secure an even larger presence in the international media market suffered a new setback on Tuesday, when a British regulator provisionally rejected 21st Century Fox’s bid to acquire full control of Sky, the British satellite broadcaster.

articles.headline: Tesla’s Elon Musk May Have Boldest Pay Plan in Corporate History
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk agreed to stay as chief executive for 10 years, with compensation tied to $50 billion leaps in Tesla’s valuation. Otherwise, he makes zero.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk agreed to stay as chief executive for 10 years, with compensation tied to $50 billion leaps in Tesla’s valuation. Otherwise, he makes zero.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last several years, there has been speculation about Elon Musk’s future at Tesla, and whether he would step down as chief executive in the next year or two.

articles.headline: Fighting Climate Change? We’re Not Even Landing a Punch
articles.snippet: Decades of diplomatic efforts to stem global warming have proven ineffectual because too many strategies have been taken off the table.
articles.abstract: Decades of diplomatic efforts to stem global warming have proven ineffectual because too many strategies have been taken off the table.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1988, when world leaders convened their first global conference on climate change, in Toronto, the Earth’s average temperature was a bit more than half a degree Celsius above the average of the last two decades of the 19th century, according to measurements by NASA.

articles.headline: Sessions Is Questioned as Russia Inquiry Focuses on Obstruction
articles.snippet: The attorney general, as well as James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, were questioned in the inquiry into Russia’s election interference and whether President Trump obstructed justice.
articles.abstract: The attorney general, as well as James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, were questioned in the inquiry into Russia’s election interference and whether President Trump obstructed justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Jeff Sessions was questioned for several hours last week as part of the special counsel investigation, the Justice Department confirmed Tuesday, making him the first member of President Trump’s cabinet to be interviewed in the inquiry.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: School Shooting in Kentucky Was Nation’s 11th of Year. It Was Jan. 23.
articles.snippet: When two students were killed by gunfire in Benton, Ky., Tuesday morning, it was at least the 11th shooting so far this year on school property.
articles.abstract: When two students were killed by gunfire in Benton, Ky., Tuesday morning, it was at least the 11th shooting so far this year on school property.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — On Tuesday, it was a high school in small-town Kentucky. On Monday, a school cafeteria outside Dallas and a charter school parking lot in New Orleans. And before that, a school bus in Iowa, a college campus in Southern California, a high school in Seattle.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder and Daniel Victor
